Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Collaborative Research: Parallel Online Algorithms for Large-Scale MRI

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This effort puts forth powerful models capturing the characteristics of big dynamic magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) data, and then offering architectures and algorithms, while revealing fundamental insights into various analytical and implementation trade-offs involved. The proposed framework will extract salient global trends to enable imputation for missing MRI data entries due to imaging speed limitations, and obtain parsimonious representations to process and draw inferences from big pools of MRI data. Leveraging advances in low-rank and sparsity-aware signal processing, learning and optimization, online, parallel, and decentralized algorithms based on matrix and tensor models, will enable streaming analytics of sequential measurements using parallel processors, and tracking dynamically evolving datasets.

This project will directly impact high-resolution 3D dynamic MRI technology to improve medical diagnosis and treatment. The developed algorithms and tools will enable technology transfer to benefit a wide population and improve healthcare. Insights gained from this project's large-scale analytics context will also benefit big data mining, neuroscience, smart grid, and health informatics. Broader impact will be further effected by the integration of the proposed research with an educational plan designed to train the new cadre of next-generation of medical data science professionals, as well as promote cross-fertilization of academic research with health industry needs.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

POR.DRECONTENT:
Machine learning from big data aspires to bring ground-breaking advances in science and engineering along with consequent improvements in quality of life. Arguably among the principal technologies to benefit from such advances is dynamic magnetic resonance imaging (dMRI). With such big promises however, come big challenges. As acquisition speeds are relatively low, only low-quality corrupted data can be collected; while the sheer volume of data can also challenge real-time reconstruction on central processors and storage units. Last but not least, it is desired to minimize scanning time but also improve imaging quality.  

This project addresses part of these challenges by putting forth powerful models capturing the characteristics of big dMRI data, as well as offering algorithms to overcome the emerging practical hurdles, while revealing fundamental insights on various analytical and implementation trade-offs involved. Capitalizing on recent advances in image processing, machine learning and optimization, sparsity and low-rank attributes are envisioned as key enablers. Emphasis is laid on concocting online, parallel, and decentralized algorithms to enable data analytics of sequential measurements using parallel processors, and tracking dynamically evolving datasets. The intellectual merit of this project's major outcomes are innovative models and parallel algorithms for real-time MRI; and data-adaptive decentralized learning for real-time MRI.

As far as impact to the public, this project advances high-resolution 3D dMRI thus enabling biomedical movies to be acquired, processed, and displayed in real time. Such capabilities will significantly enrich the information provided by MRI and highlight key features that distinguish abnormalities from normalities, thus improving medical diagnosis and treatment. The developed algorithms and tools will enable technology transfer to benefit a wide population and improve healthcare. Insights gained from this project’s large-scale analytics context will also permeate benefits to a gamut of other exciting problem domains, including big data mining, neuroscience, smart grid, and health informatics.

 


Last Modified: 10/04/2017
Modified by: Georgios B Giannakis
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Machine learning from big data aspires to bring ground-breaking advances in science and engineering along with consequent improvements in quality of life. Arguably among the principal technologies to benefit from such advances is dynamic magnetic resonance imaging (dMRI). With such big promises however, come big challenges. As acquisition speeds are relatively low, only low-quality corrupted data can be collected; while the sheer volume of data can also challenge real-time reconstruction on central processors and storage units. Last but not least, it is desired to minimize scanning time but also improve imaging quality. This project addresses part of these challenges by putting forth powerful models capturing the characteristics of big dMRI data, as well as offering algorithms to overcome the emerging practical hurdles, while revealing fundamental insights on various analytical and implementation trade-offs involved. Capitalizing on recent advances in image processing, machine learning and optimization, sparsity and low-rank attributes are envisioned as key enablers. Emphasis is laid on concocting online, parallel, and decentralized algorithms to enable data analytics of sequential measurements using parallel processors, and tracking dynamically evolving datasets. The intellectual merit of this project's major outcomes are innovative models and parallel algorithms for real-time MRI; and data-adaptive decentralized learning for real-time MRI. As far as impact to the public, this project advances high-resolution 3D dMRI thus enabling biomedical movies to be acquired, processed, and displayed in real time. Such capabilities will significantly enrich the information provided by MRI and highlight key features that distinguish abnormalities from normalities, thus improving medical diagnosis and treatment. The developed algorithms and tools will enable technology transfer to benefit a wide population and improve healthcare. Insights gained from this project?s large-scale analytics context will also permeate benefits to a gamut of other exciting problem domains, including big data mining, neuroscience, smart grid, and health informatics.
